Chiricahua Apache Text 18. Coyote Marries his Own Daughter as told by Sam Kenoi Coyote lived with his many children. (18.1) Ma'ye biche'shke łáͅgo hiłnaaheestáͅná'a. Bijeekeͅ' 'íłtsénaagháń ńnánzhóͅ. Yaabóó n diiná'a. Coyote lived with his many children. His oldest daughter was very pretty. He wanted to marry her. Then he pretended to be sick. (18.2) Nágo kaa'ígodeestíͅná'a. Bigha'isdzáń 'áił n díná'a. "Doonzhóͅdago kaasítíͅ." yiił n díná'a. "'Aaí ditsiͅ 'óó'áí bikáyá téesk'eh shá'ágólá. 'Ákaa dashisíłtee." gooł n díná'a. Then he pretended to be sick. He spoke thus to his wife: "I am badly sick." he said to her. "Make me a bed on that tree that stands there. Put me up there." he said to her. Then his wife made a bed for him there. (18.3) 'Ákoo bigha'isdzáńń 'ákaa téesk'eh bá'ágólaaná'a. Then his wife made a bed for him there. Then he lay down up there. (18.4) Nágo 'ákaa dahneestíͅná'a. Ha'shíͅń 'izi hóółdzi'í náyíń'áͅná'a. Bit'ahyá nyíń'áͅná'a. Then he lay down up there. From somewhere he had brought a liver back that was rotten. He had put this by his side. Then he spoke thus to his wife: (18.5) Nágo bigha'isdzáńń 'áił n díná'a. "'Ádzáͅáͅee shitł'áhee dá'ałtsojíͅda góshó. Ch'osh naaniidágo, doonshóńlídadaał. 'Ákoo daahka. Dáháń dlóͅí łik'aaí díͅíͅ' yajishgo nahdáhíłghoń baagodaałtééł. 'Aań 'íłtsénaagháń baagodaałtééł." gooł n díná'a. Then he spoke thus to his wife: "Sweep right here under me every day. When worms begin to fall, you will know I am gone. 1 Then you will go away. You will give [my daughter] to anyone you meet carrying four fat prairie dogs. You will give him the oldest one." he said to her. He had sexual desires toward his daughter. So he spoke thus. (18.6) Bijeekeͅ'nń hich'iͅiͅnabóó n dii. Nágo 'á n díná'a. He had sexual desires toward his daughter. So he spoke thus. They knew him by a large wart that was on the side of his head. (18.7) Bíńtł'ayá soͅoͅs ntsaaí baadasi'áͅí beebégóziͅná'a They knew him by a large wart that was on the side of his head. 2 Then, every day, his wife swept [the ground] under him. (18.8) Ákoo dá'ałtso jíͅda, bitł'áhee gojishóná'a Łai jíͅgo 'iziní łáͅgo ch'osh baagooslíͅná'a. Nágo ch'oshí naaya n diłná'a. Then, every day, his wife swept [the ground] under him. One day there appeared many worms on that liver. And he was dropping the worms down [to the ground]. Then, the next day, his wife was coming again to the place under him. (18.9) Nágo łai jíͅgo, bigha'isdzáńń bitł'áshíͅ náánóołghołná'a. Ch'osh 'isda'yees n dilí nii'yá yaahees n dilgo, yiiłtsáͅná'a. T'áͅyá biche'shkéne yaanáłghoná'a. Hichaná'a. Then, the next day, his wife was coming again to the place under him. She saw the worms he had dropped lying scattered about on the ground. She went back to her children. She was weeping. "The worms have fallen. We shall go right away. 'When the worms fall, you will go.' he said to us." (18.10) "Ch'osh naaneesdaa. Haͅh hooká. 'Ch'osh naaniidágo, daahka,' nałji n dín." biche'shkéneí daayiił n díná'a. "The worms have fallen. We shall go right away. 'When the worms fall, you will go.' he said to us." she said to her children. Sadly, they started off. (18.11) Joodaajibááyégo, jideeskaná'a. Dásí haná'an 'ijikáyá, 'áń bizáͅáͅyéń, 'ikéyánaagháń, t'áͅyá ditsiͅ 'óó'aní 'ákaa nádeesgalná'a. Ditsiͅ 'óó'ání' bikáshíͅ bitaanń yaanáałghogo yiiłtsáͅná'a. Sadly, they started off. When they were nearly out of sight, the small one, the youngest one, looked back to the tree that stood there. He saw his father jumping from the tree that stood there. Then he spoke thus to his mother: (18.12) Nágo bimáń 'áyiił n díná'a: "Shimá, ditsiͅ 'óó'ání bikáshiͅ shitaa yaanáałgho 'íyéhé !" gooł n díná'a. Then he spoke thus to his mother: "My mother, [I'm] sure my father jumped from the tree that stands there!" he said to her. Then his mother spoke thus to him: (18.13) Nágo bimáń 'áyiił n díná'a. "Doo'áji n dída, shishke'é. 'Iłk'idáͅ 'édiͅiͅ. Doojózjída." bimáń biił n díná'a Then his mother spoke thus to him: "Do not say so, my child. He is gone long ago. Do not mention him." his mother said to him 3 In spite of that, the little one spoke thus to his mother: (18.14) Dá'ághát'éndah, 'áń bizáͅáͅyéń bimáń 'áyiił n díná'a: "Dooda, dishdí ! Dooda, dishdí ! Shitaa 'át'íͅ ! Dábí 'át'íͅ !" n díná'a. In spite of that, the little one spoke thus to his mother: "No, I say! No, I say! It was my father! It was certainly him!" he said. But then his mother stopped him. (18.15) Dá'ághát'éndah bimáń bich'aaghagóchiͅná'a. n Dáséyá jakaná'a. But then his mother stopped him. They went on. Then, at a place still further on, that Coyote himself, carrying four prairie dogs, met his children. (18.16) Nágo, nááná n dáséee, 'áń Ma'yeń bichee'shkénení dábíní dlóͅí díͅíͅ' yajishgo, godáhíłghoná'a. Goghaͅ'nń gochiͅiͅyáłti ndah doobégojísiͅdaná'a. Then, at a place still further on, that Coyote himself, carrying four prairie dogs, met his children. Her husband talked to her but she did not recognize him. Then that Coyote, when he met his children, spoke thus to them: (18.17) Nágo 'áń Ma'yenń biche'shkéní hidánáłghozhiͅ, 'ádaił n díná'a: "Ha'yáhee joodaanahabááyéyo dahkáná?" daayiił n díná'a. Then that Coyote, when he met his children, spoke thus to them: "Where are you who look so sad going?" he said to them. Then his wife spoke thus to him: (18.18) Nágo bighaa'isdzáńń 'ábiił n díná'a: "'Ch'osh naaniidágo, daahka,' nałji n dí. Ákoo ch'osh naaneesdaa. 'Íbaͅaͅ 'áshíͅ hooka. 'Éjidiͅn. n díná'a. Then his wife spoke thus to him: "'When the worms fall, you will go,' he said to us. Then the worms fell. Therefore we are travelling here. He has gone." she said. Then, though it was indeed him, he spoke thus to her: (18.19) Nágo dábí 'át'íͅ ndah, 'ágooł n díná'a: "Haastiͅiͅí gojíyáͅłee. 'Iyáada ji n díná'a, hálí?" gooł n díná'a. Then, though it was indeed him, he spoke thus to her: "The old man was wise. He said some thing else, no doubt?" he said to her. Then she spoke thus to him: (18.20) Nágo 'áałji n díná'a: "'Ao. 'Dáhaań dlóͅí díͅíͅ' yajishń díń jeekeͅ' 'íłtsénaagháń baadaałtééł,' shiłji n dín." n díná'a. Then she spoke thus to him: "Yes. 'You will give this oldest girl to anyone who carries four prairie dogs.' he said to me." she said. Then he spoke thus to her: (18.21) Nágo 'ágooł n díná'a: "Ághát'é, dish n dí, gojíyáͅłee !" n díná'a. Then he spoke thus to her: "It is so, I say, he was wise!" he said. Then she gave him her oldest daughter. (18.22) Nágo bijeekeͅ' 'íłtsénaaghánń baajíńłtíͅná'a. Kooghaͅ bá'ágojiláná'a. Bijeekeͅ'nń, bigha'isdzáńgo, yiłsikéná'a sháͅ'shíͅ. Then she gave him her oldest daughter. She made a wickiup for him. 4 His daughter, being his wife, sat with him in the sun. "My wife, search for lice on me." (18.23) Nágo bijeekeͅ'nń 'áił n díná'a: "Shigha'isdzáń, yaa sháháńghaał." yiił n díná'a. "My wife, search for lice on me." he said to her. Putting his head in her lap, he lay on his side as she searched for lice on him. (18.24) Gotsaask'ideyá nneet'áͅgo, nanneestíͅgo yaa báhájintáná'a. Bíńtł'ashíͅ soͅoͅs ntsaaí baadasi''áͅí beebégóziͅná'a. 'Áshíͅgo hik'izhiͅiͅ nees'áͅná'a. 'Áshíͅgo 'inááshdiyał n di. Putting his head in her lap, he lay on his side as she searched for lice on him. They knew him by a large wart that was on the side of his head. His head lay on that side. She put her hand there every now and then. Then he spoke thus to her: (18.25) Nágo 'ágooł n díná'a: "'Iͅiͅshíͅgo shégoja." gooł n dígo, soͅoͅs ntsaaí baadasi'áͅshégo doodashdił n dikaahát'íͅdaná'a. Dáhágooh n dii, 'iiłhaazhná'a. Then he spoke thus to her: "They are on this side of me." he said, not permitting her to put her hand on the side on which the big wart lay. Suddenly, he fell asleep. Then that girl thought thus. (18.26) Nágo 'áń jeekeͅ'ń 'áyinzíͅná'a. "Haͅaͅshaͅ, 'iyáabaͅaͅ 'iͅiͅshíͅgo dooda'dihát'íͅda?" jíńziͅgo, dá'iłhoshgo 'áshíͅgo k'éshdeesghalná'a. Then that girl thought thus. "Let's see, why does he not allow me to put my hand on this side?" she thought, looking on that side as he slept. And a big wart was on the side of his head! (18.27) Nágo bíńtł'ashíͅ soͅoͅs ntsaaí baadasi'áͅná'a ! Gotaanń 'át'íͅná'a ! Dá'iłhoshgo, kóͅóͅhégo bitł'áh hajałtsaná'a. Gomáń bich'iͅiͅnájiiłteená'a. Gomáń 'áałji n díná'a: "Shimá, 'ágháń shitaanń 'át'íͅ ! Bíńtł'ashíͅ soͅoͅs ntsaí baadasi'á ! 'Áíbee dábí 'át'íͅí bégóziͅ !" gooł n díná'a. And a big wart was on the side of his head! It was her father! As he slept, she slipped quietly out from under him. She ran back to her mother. She spoke thus to her mother: "My mother, that one is my father! A big wart lies on the side of his head! That shows that it is surely him!" she said to her. She went back to him with her mother. (18.28) Bich'iͅiͅnáshdiyeest'áázhná'a, dágomáńbił Dá'iłhoshná'a Baanájít'áázhná'a. Bíńtł'aashíͅ bik'éshdeesghalná'a. Dá n dí dábí 'át'íͅná'a ! She went back to him with her mother. He was still asleep. The two of them went to him. They looked at the side of his head. It was indeed him! [The mother] picked up a big stone. (18.29) Tséntsaaí náshn'áͅná'a. Gotsiit'á dahjiis'áͅná'a. 'Iłhoshzhiͅ bik'izhiͅ njíńyáná'a. Bitsii tsé k'eejiiłkaaná'a. Jiyeesxíͅná'a. [The mother] picked up a big stone. She put it on top of her head. She stood over him where he slept. She threw the stone on his head. She had killed him. Linguistic Notes by Harry Hoijer (18.1) Linguistic Notes 1. hiłnaaheestáͅná'a 'he lived with them'. Literally: 'he sat about with them'. 3rd person of naa-hi-...- táͅ 'several sit about' [si- perf. neut. intr.]. A plural verb.is used here because the total number is more than one. 2. bijeekeͅ' 'his daughter'. 3. 'íłtsénaagháń 'she who was oldest': 'íłtsé 'first'; naaghá 'she lives, she goes about' [see linguistic note to Chiricahua text 4.9 §4]. 4. yaabóó n diiná'a 'he wanted to marry her'. yaa- 'to her'; bóó n dii 'he has sexual desire, he wants, desires'. Bi- 3rd person pronoun plus hoo- and a stem - n dii. (18.2) Linguistic Notes 1. kaa'ígodeestíͅná'a 'he pretended to be sick'. 3rd person perf. of kaa- 'í -go-di- ...[si- perf.]- ł -tee 'to pretend to be sick' [act. intr.]. kaa- 'sickness, disease' [a noun]. The prefix complex í -go-di- apparently means 'to pretend to be'. This theme is obviously neither -tee 'one person lies' nor - ł -tee 'to handle an animate being'. It may be a mediopassive in which the signs of the -l- class have entirely disappeared. 2. - gha'isdzáń 'wife'. Apparently a compound of -gha-, a unique morpheme, and 'isdzáń 'woman'. 3. kaasítíͅ 'I am sick'. kaa 'sickness' plus the 1st person of - tíͅ 'one animate being lies' [si- perf. neut. intr.]. Cf. §1 above. 4. téesk'eh 'bed, sleeping place'. (18.4) Linguistic Notes 'izi hóółdzi'í 'a liver that was rotten'. -zi liver'. hóółdzi' , perf. of ...[hi- perf.]- ł -dzi 'to become rotten' [act. intr.]. (18.5) Linguistic Notes 1. dá'ałtsojíͅda 'every day'. dá - just'; 'ałtso [or 'iłtso ] 'all, every'; jíͅ 'day' ; -da 'only, even'. 2. góshó 'you sweep it'. 2nd person imp. with place object of ...[hi- perf.]- ł - zho 'to sweep, brush' [act. tr.]. 3. doonshóńlídadaał 'you will know I am gone'. Negative with future enclitic - daał of the 2nd person with 1st person object of ni-0 ó -...- lí 'to expect someone, to hope for someone'. Literally: 'you will not hope for me'; a euphemistic way of saying 'you will know I am dead'. 4. baagodaałtééł 'you will give her to him'. 2nd person dual future with 3a object of 0aa-ni-...[ni- perf.]- ł -tee 'to give someone an animate being' [act. tr.] aa- 'to'; ni- completive. The latter prefix appears only in the imp. mode. Why Coyote should use the 2nd person dual when addressing his wife is not clear. The 2nd person dual is a polite form of address generally applied only to those relatives with which one maintains a respect relationship. (18.6) Linguistic Notes hich'iͅiͅnabóó n dii 'he had sexual desires toward her'. hich'iͅiͅ 'toward her'; na- ? bóó n dii see note 18:1, §4. (18.9) Linguistic Notes biche'shkéne 'her children'; -ne 'people of such and such a group. (18.12) Linguistic Notes 'íyéhé a particle denoting certainty: 'surely, positively'. (18.15) Linguistic Notes bich'aaghagóchiͅná'a 'she stopped him. 3rd person imp. of 0-ch'aa-gha-go-ni-...[hi- perf.]- chiͅ 'to forbid someone, to stop someone [from doing]'. The prefix complex cannot be defined. (18.16) Linguistic Notes goghaͅ'nń 'her husband'. - ghaͅ' 'husband'; -n past tense. (18.19) Linguistic Notes gojíyáͅłee 'he was wise'. 3a person of go-ni-...- yáͅ 'to be wise, sensible' [imp. Neut. Intr.; go- ?; ni- adj.]. - łee 'it used to be. (18.22) Linguistic Notes 1. yiłsikéná'a 'she sat with him' yił - with him' plus 3rd person of ké 'two persons sit' [si- perf. neut. intr.]. Note the dual verb with a singular subject [cf. note 18.1; §1]. 2. sháͅ' 'sunshine, rays of the sun'. (18.23) Linguistic Notes yaa sháháńghaał 'search or lice on me'. yaa 'lice'. shá - 'for me' plus 2nd person imp. Of há -di-...[si- perf.]- ghaał 'to search for' [act. intr.]. In this verb the prefix há - 'for' is evidently an archaic combination of a pronoun object plus a postposition. When any other than the 3rd person pronoun is expressed, the postposition becomes - ká 'for'; thus, shíkáńghaał 'look for me'. In other verbs, however, há - is treated as a non- postpositional prefix and the verb is transitive [see linguistic note to Chiricahua text 1.19, §4]. (18.24) Linguistic Notes 1. gotsaask'ideyá 'in her lap'. - tsaask'ide 'lap'; no analysis. 2. nneet'áͅgo 'putting his head'. 3rd person perf. of ni-ne-ni-...[ni- perf.]-d- aa 'to move one's head to a stop' [mediopas.]. ni- to a stop'; ne-ni- ?. The theme is probably 'to handle a round object'; thus, the mediopassive -d-aa 'to handle one's own round object [i. e., one's head]'. ne-ni-[the ni- is probably the perf. prefix] combine to nee- in the 3rd person perf. [cf. nnenst'áͅ 'I have put my head down']. 3. nanneestíͅgo 'he lay on his side'. 3rd person perf. of nan-ni-...[si- perf.]-tee 'one person lies on his side' [act. intr.; nan- 'on [his] side'; ni- terminative]. 4. 'inááshdiyał n di 'she put her hand [there] every now and then'. 'i- 'away'; náá - 'again and again'; di-yi- ? plus the prog. mode of - ł - n di 'to make a movement of the hands' [act. intr.]. This prefix complex appears only in the prog. (18.25) Linguistic Notes 1. shégoja 'several are on me'. Analysis uncertain. shé - is probably shi- 'me' plus é - 'against, on' [pp.]. goja, however, is not clear. It may be a form of the theme - jaa 'several lie' [act. Intr.] but the mode cannot be identified. 2. doodashdił n dikaahát'íͅdaná'a 'he did not permit her to put her hand [there]'. doodashdił n di , 3a person imp. of dah-di-...[si- perf.]-l- [ n di 'to move one's hands about' [mediopas.; dah- 'on'; di- ?]. kaahát'íͅ is probably a mishearing of kááhát'íͅ ; 'he permits, allows her' [see linguistic note to Chiricahua text 2.6, §1]. (18.27) Linguistic Notes hajałtsaná'a 'she slipped out'. 3a person perf. of 0-k'ee-hi|...[hi- perf.]-l- tsáá 'to slip out, to move while sitting' [mediopas.; ha- 'out']. (18.29) Linguistic Notes k'eejiiłkaaná'a , 'she threw it on it'. 3a person imp. of 0-k'ee-hi-|...[ni- perf.]- ł - kaa 'to throw a large flat object on someone' [act. tr.; kee- on'; hi- ?]. In the text, bitsi- 'his head' apparently makes the pronoun object before k'ee- unnecessary. Ethnological Notes Morris Opler Ethnological Note 1 "To be gone" is the accepted euphemism for death. Ethnological Note 2 That is, the members of Coyote's family knew that he had a large wart on the side of his head. The informant did not know this tale very well, and, in the first telling of it, omitted this detail which is important later [see paragraph 23, et. seq.]. He afterward made this insertion which is, therefore, curiously out of context. Ethnological Note 3 Mention of the dead is forbidden by the Apache, especially in the presence of relatives of the deceased. Ethnological Note 4 Residence among the Chiricahua is matrilocal. The girl's mother, with the help of other female relatives, constructs a wickiup for the newly married couple not very far distant from her own home. House building is the work of the women.
